And live, as we do, in this wilderness?

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.l: What say'st thou? wilt thou be of our consort?
Say ay, and be the captain of us all:
We'll do thee homage and be ruled by thee,
Love thee as our commander and our king.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.l: But if thou scorn our courtesy, thou diest.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.l: Thou shalt not live to brag what we have offered.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: I take your offer and will live with you,
Provided that you do no outrages
On silly women or poor passengers.

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.l: No, we detest such vile base practices.
Come, go with us, we'll bring thee to our crews,
And show thee all the treasure we have got;
Which, with ourselves, all rest at thy dispose. Exeunt.

div.head: Act 4, Scene 2
div.stage: Milan. Outside the DUKE'S palace, under SILVIA'S chamber.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Already have I been false to Valentine
And now I must be as unjust to Thurio.
Under the colour of commending him,
I have access my own love to prefer:
But Silvia is too fair, too true, too holy,
To be corrupted with my worthless gifts.
When I protest true loyalty to her,
She twits me with my falsehood to my friend;
When to her beauty I commend my vows,
She bids me think how I have been forsworn
In breaking faith with Julia whom I loved:
And notwithstanding all her sudden quips,
The least whereof would quell a lover's hope,
Yet, spaniel-like, the more she spurns my love,
The more it grows and fawneth on her still.
But here comes Thurio: now must we to her window,
And give some evening music to her ear. Enter THURIO and Musicians.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: How now, Sir Proteus, are you crept before us?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Ay, gentle Thurio: for you know that love
Will creep in service where it cannot go.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Ay, but I hope, sir, that you love not here.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Sir, but I do; or else I would be hence.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Who? Silvia?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Ay, Silvia; for your sake.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: I thank you for your own. Now, gentlemen,
Let's tune, and to it lustily awhile. Enter, at a distance, HOST, and JULIA in boy's clothes.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Now, my young guest, methinks you're allicholly: I
pray you, why is it?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Marry, mine host, because I cannot be merry.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Come, we'll have you merry: I'll bring you where
you shall hear music and see the gentleman that you
asked for.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: But shall I hear him speak?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Ay, that you shall.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: That will be music.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Hark, hark!

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Is he among these?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Ay, but, peace let's hear 'em.

sp.l: Who is Silvia? what is she,
That all our swains commend her?
Holy, fair and wise is she;
The heaven such grace did lend her,
That she might admired be.
Is she kind as she is fair?
For beauty lives with kindness.
Love doth to her eyes repair,
To help him of his blindness,
And, being helped, inhabits there.
Then to Silvia let us sing,
That Silvia is excelling;
She excels each mortal thing
Upon the dull earth dwelling:
To her let us garlands bring.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: How now! are you sadder than you were before? How do
you, man? the music likes you not.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: You mistake; the musician likes me not.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Why, my pretty youth?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: He plays false, father.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: How? out of tune on the strings?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Not so; but yet so false that he grieves my very
heartstrings.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: You have a quick ear.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Ay, I would I were deaf; it makes me have a slow
heart.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: I perceive you delight not in music.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Not a whit, when it jars so.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Hark, what fine change is in the music!

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Ay, that change is the spite.

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: You would have them always play but one thing?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: I would always have one play but one thing.
But, host, doth this Sir Proteus that we talk on
Often resort unto this gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: I tell you what Launce, his man, told me: he loved her
out of all nick.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Where is Launce?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Gone to seek his dog; which to-morrow, by his
master's command, he must carry for a present to his
lady.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Peace! stand aside: the company parts.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Sir Thurio, fear not you: I will so plead
That you shall say my cunning drift excels.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Where meet we?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: At Saint Gregory's well.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Farewell. Exeunt Thu. and Musicians. Enter SILVIA above.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Madam, good even to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: I thank you for your music, gentlemen. Who is that that spake?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: One, lady, if you knew his pure heart's truth,
You would quickly learn to know him by his voice.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Sir Proteus, as I take it.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Sir Proteus, gentle lady, and your servant.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: What's your will?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: That I may compass yours.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: You have your wish; my will is even this:
That presently you hie you home to bed.
Thou subtle, perjured, false, disloyal man!
Think'st thou I am so shallow, so conceitless,
To be seduced by thy flattery,
That hast deceived so many with thy vows?
Return, return and make thy love amends.
For me, by this pale queen of night I swear,
I am so far from granting thy request
That I despise thee for thy wrongful suit,
And by and by intend to chide myself
Even for this time I spend in talking to thee.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: I grant, sweet love, that I did love a lady;
But she is dead.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: 'Twere false, if I should speak it;
For I am sure she is not buried.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Say that she be; yet Valentine thy friend
Survives; to whom, thyself art witness,
I am betrothed: and art thou not ashamed
To wrong him with thy importunacy?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: I likewise hear that Valentine is dead.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: And so suppose am I; for in his grave
Assure thyself my love is buried.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Sweet lady, let me rake it from the earth.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Go to thy lady's grave and call hers thence.
Or, at the least, in hers sepulchre thine.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: He heard not that.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Madam, if your heart be so obdurate,
Vouchsafe me yet your picture for my love,
The picture that is hanging in your chamber;
To that I'll speak, to that I'll sigh and weep;
For since the substance of your perfect self
Is else devoted, I am but a shadow;
And to your shadow will I make true love.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: If 'twere a substance, you would, sure, deceive it,
And make it but a shadow, as I am.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: I am very loath to be your idol, sir;
But since your falsehood shall become you well
To worship shadows and adore false shapes,
Send to me in the morning and I'll send it:
And so, good rest.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: As wretches have overnight
That wait for execution in the morn. Exeunt Pro. and Sil. severally.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Host, will you go?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: By my halidom, I was fast asleep.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: Pray you, where lies Sir Proteus?

sp.speaker: Host
sp.ab: Marry, at my house. Trust me, I think 'tis almost day.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Not so; but it hath been the longest night
That e'er I watched and the most heaviest. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Eglamour
sp.l: This is the hour that Madam Silvia
Entreated me to call and know her mind:
There's some great matter she'ld employ me in.
Madam, madam! Enter SILVIA above.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Who calls?

sp.speaker: Eglamour
sp.l: Your servant and your friend;
One that attends your ladyship's command.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Sir Eglamour, a thousand times good morrow.

sp.speaker: Eglamour
sp.l: As many, worthy lady, to yourself:
According to your ladyship's impose,
I am thus early come to know what service
It is your pleasure to command me in.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: O Eglamour, thou art a gentleman —
Think not I flatter, for I swear I do not —
Valiant, wise, remorseful, well accomplished,
Thou art not ignorant what dear good will
I bear unto the banished Valentine
Nor how my father would enforce me marry
Vain Thurio, whom my very soul abhors.
Thyself hast loved; and I have heard thee say
No grief did ever come so near thy heart
As when thy lady and thy true-love died,
Upon whose grave thou vowedst pure chastity.
Sir Eglamour, I would to Valentine,
To Mantua, where I hear he makes abode;
And, for the ways are dangerous to pass,
I do desire thy worthy company,
Upon whose faith and honour I repose.
Urge not my father's anger, Eglamour,
But think upon my grief, a lady's grief,
And on the justice of my flying hence,
To keep me from a most unholy match,
Which heaven and fortune still rewards with plagues.
I do desire thee, even from a heart
As full of sorrows as the sea of sands,
To bear me company and go with me:
If not, to hide what I have said to thee,
That I may venture to depart alone.

sp.speaker: Eglamour
sp.l: Madam, I pity much your grievances;
Which since I know they virtuously are placed,
I give consent to go along with you,
Recking as little what betideth me
As much I wish all good befortune you.
When will you go?

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: This evening coming.

sp.speaker: Eglamour
sp.l: Where shall I meet you?

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: At Friar Patrick's cell,
Where I intend holy confession.

sp.speaker: Eglamour
sp.ab: I will not fail your ladyship. Good morrow, gentle
lady.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.ab: Good morrow, kind Sir Eglamour.

sp.speaker: Launce
sp.ab: When a man's servant shall play the cur with him,
look you, it goes hard: one that I brought up of
a puppy; one that I saved from drowning, when
three or four of his blind brothers and sisters
went to it. I have taught him, even as one would
say precisely, “thus I would teach a dog.” I was
sent to deliver him as a present to Mistress
Silvia from my master; and I came no sooner into
the dining-chamber but he steps me to her trencher
and steals her capon's leg: O, 'tis a foul thing
when a cur cannot keep himself in all companies!
I would have, as one should say, one that takes
upon him to be a dog indeed, to be, as it were,
a dog at all things. If I had not had more wit
than he, to take a fault upon me that he did, I
think verily he had been hanged for't; sure as
I live, he had suffered for't; you shall judge.
He thrusts me himself into the company of three
or four gentleman-like dogs, under the duke's
table: he had not been there — bless the mark! — a
pissing-while, but all the chamber smelt him.
“Out with the dog!” says one: “What cur is that?”
says another: “Whip him out” says the third:
“Hang him up” says the duke. I, having been
acquainted with the smell before knew it was
Crab, and goes me to the fellow that whips the
dogs: “Friend,” quoth I, “you mean to whip the
dog?” “Ay, marry, do I,” quoth he. “You do him
the more wrong,” quoth I; “'twas I did the thing
you wot of.” He makes me no more ado, but whips
me out of the chamber. How many masters would do
this for his servant? Nay, I'll be sworn, I have
sat in the stocks for puddings he hath stolen,
otherwise he had been executed; I have stood on
the pillory for geese he hath killed, otherwise
he had suffered for't. Thou thinkest not of this
now. Nay, I remember the trick you served me when
I took my leave of Madam Silvia: did not I bid
thee still mark me and do as I do? when didst
thou see me heave up my leg and make water against
a gentlewoman's farthingale? didst thou ever see me do
such a trick?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Sebastian is thy name? I like thee well
And will employ thee in some service presently.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: In what you please: I'll do what I can.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: I hope thou wilt. To Launce How now, you whoreson peasant!
Where have you been these two days loitering?

sp.speaker: Launce
sp.ab: Marry, sir, I carried Mistress Silvia the dog you bade
me.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: And what says she to my little jewel?

sp.speaker: Launce
sp.ab: Marry, she says your dog was a cur, and tells
you currish thanks is good enough for such a present.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: But she received my dog?

sp.speaker: Launce
sp.ab: No, indeed, did she not: here have I brought him back
again.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: What, didst thou offer her this from me?

sp.speaker: Launce
sp.ab: Ay, sir; the other squirrel was stolen from me
by the hangman's boys in the marketplace: and
then I offered her mine own, who is a dog as big
as ten of yours, and therefore the gift the greater.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Go get thee hence, and find my dog again,
Or ne'er return again into my sight.
Away, I say! stay'st thou to vex me here? Exit Launce.
A slave, that still an end turns me to shame!
Sebastian, I have entertained thee,
Partly that I have need of such a youth
That can with some discretion do my business,
For 'tis no trusting to yond foolish lout,
But chiefly for thy face and thy behaviour,
Which, if my augury deceive me not,
Witness good bringing up, fortune and truth:
Therefore know thou, for this I entertain thee.
Go presently and take this ring with thee,
Deliver it to Madam Silvia:
She loved me well delivered it to me.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: It seems you loved not her, to leave her token.
She is dead, belike?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Not so; I think she lives.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Alas!

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Why dost thou cry “alas”?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: I cannot choose but pity her.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Wherefore shouldst thou pity her?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Because methinks that she loved you as well
As you do love your lady Silvia:
She dreams on him that has forgot her love;
You dote on her that cares not for your love.
'Tis pity love should be so contrary;
And thinking on it makes me cry “alas!”

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Well, give her that ring and therewithal
This letter. That's her chamber. Tell my lady
I claim the promise for her heavenly picture.
Your message done, hie home unto my chamber,
Where thou shalt find me, sad and solitary. Exit.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: How many women would do such a message?
Alas, poor Proteus! thou hast entertained
A fox to be the shepherd of thy lambs.
Alas, poor fool! why do I pity him
That with his very heart despiseth me?
Because he loves her, he despiseth me;
Because I love him, I must pity him.
This ring I gave him when he parted from me,
To bind him to remember my good will;
And now am I, unhappy messenger,
To plead for that which I would not obtain,
To carry that which I would have refused,
To praise his faith which I would have dispraised.
I am my master's true confirmed love;
But cannot be true servant to my master,
Unless I prove false traitor to myself.
Yet will I woo for him, but yet so coldly
As, heaven it knows, I would not have him speed. Enter SILVIA, attended.
Gentlewoman, good day! I pray you, be my mean
To bring me where to speak with Madam Silvia.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: What would you with her, if that I be she?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: If you be she, I do entreat your patience
To hear me speak the message I am sent on.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: From whom?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: From my master, Sir Proteus, madam.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: O, he sends you for a picture.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Ay, madam.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Ursula, bring my picture there.
Go give your master this: tell him from me,
One Julia, that his changing thoughts forget,
Would better fit his chamber than this shadow.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Madam, please you peruse this letter. —
Pardon me, madam; I have unadvised
Delivered you a paper that I should not:
This is the letter to your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: I pray thee, let me look on that again.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: It may not be; good madam, pardon me.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: There, hold!
I will not look upon your master's lines:
I know they are stuffed with protestations
And full of new-found oaths; which he will break
As easily as I do tear his paper.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Madam, he sends your ladyship this ring.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: The more shame for him that he sends it me;
For I have heard him say a thousand times
His Julia gave it him at his departure.
Though his false finger have profaned the ring,
Mine shall not do his Julia so much wrong.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: She thanks you.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: What say'st thou?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: I thank you, madam, that you tender her.
Poor gentlewoman! my master wrongs her much.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Dost thou know her?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Almost as well as I do know myself:
To think upon her woes I do protest
That I have wept a hundred several times.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Belike she thinks that Proteus hath forsook her.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: I think she doth; and that's her cause of sorrow.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Is she not passing fair?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: She hath been fairer, madam, than she is:
When she did think my master loved her well,
She, in my judgement, was as fair as you;
But since she did neglect her looking-glass
And threw her sun-expelling mask away,
The air hath starved the roses in her cheeks
And pinched the lily-tincture of her face,
That now she is become as black as I.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: How tall was she?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: About my stature; for at Pentecost,
When all our pageants of delight were played,
Our youth got me to play the woman's part,
And I was trimmed in Madam Julia's gown,
Which served me as fit, by all men's judgements,
As if the garment had been made for me:
Therefore I know she is about my height.
And at that time I made her weep agood,
For I did play a lamentable part:
Madam, 'twas Ariadne passioning
For Theseus' perjury and unjust flight;
Which I so lively acted with my tears
That my poor mistress, moved therewithal,
Wept bitterly; and would I might be dead
If I in thought felt not her very sorrow!

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: She is beholding to thee, gentle youth.
Alas, poor lady, desolate and left!
I weep myself to think upon thy words.
Here, youth, there is my purse; I give thee this
For thy sweet mistress' sake, because thou lovest her.
Farewell. Exit Silvia, with attendants.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: And she shall thank you for't, if e'er you know her.
A virtuous gentlewoman, mild and beautiful!
I hope my master's suit will be but cold,
Since she respects my mistress' love so much,
Alas, how love can trifle with itself!
Here is her picture; let me see; I think,
If I had such a tire, this face of mine
Were full as lovely as is this of hers:
And yet the painter flattered her a little,
Unless I flatter with myself too much.
Her hair is auburn, mine is perfect yellow:
If that be all the difference in his love,
I'll get me such a coloured periwig.
Her eyes are grey as glass, and so are mine:
Ay, but her forehead's low, and mine's as high,
What should it be that he respects in her
But I can make respective in myself,
If this fond love were not a blinded god?
Come, shadow, come, and take this shadow up,
For 'tis thy rival. O thou senseless form,
Thou shalt be worshipped, kissed, loved and adored!
And, were there sense in his idolatry,
My substance should be statue in thy stead.
I'll use thee kindly for thy mistress' sake,
That used me so; or else, by Jove I vow,
I should have scratched out your unseeing eyes,
To make my master out of love with thee! Exit.

sp.speaker: Eglamour
sp.l: The sun begins to gild the western sky;
And now it is about the very hour
That Silvia, at Friar Patrick's cell, should meet me.
She will not fail, for lovers break not hours.
Unless it be to come before their time;
So much they spur their expedition.
See where she comes. Enter SILVIA.
Lady, a happy evening!

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Amen, amen! Go on, good Eglamour,
Out at the postern by the abbey wall:
I fear I am attended by some spies.

sp.speaker: Eglamour
sp.l: Fear not: the forest is not three leagues off;
If we recover that, we are sure enough. Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Sir Proteus, what says Silvia to my suit?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: O, sir, I find her milder than she was;
And yet she takes exceptions at your person.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: What, that my leg is too long?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: No; that it is too little.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: I'll wear a boot, to make it somewhat rounder.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: But love will not be spurred to what it loathes.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: What says she to my face?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: She says it is a fair one.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Nay then, the wanton lies; my face is black.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: But pearls are fair; and the old saying is,
Black men are pearls in beauteous ladies' eyes.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: 'Tis true; such pearls as put out ladies' eyes;
For I had rather wink than look on them.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: How likes she my discourse?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Ill, when you talk of war.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: But well, when I discourse of love and peace?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: But better, indeed, when you hold your peace.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: What says she to my valour?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: O, sir, she makes no doubt of that.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: She needs not, when she knows it cowardice.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: What says she to my birth?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: That you are well derived.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: True; from a gentleman to a fool.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Considers she my possessions?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: O, ay; and pities them.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Wherefore?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: That such an ass should owe them.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: That they are out by lease.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Here comes the duke. Enter DUKE.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: How now, Sir Proteus! how now, Thurio!
Which of you saw Eglamour of late?

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Not I.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Nor I.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Saw you my daughter?

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Neither.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Why then,
She's fled unto that peasant Valentine;
And Eglamour is in her company.
'Tis true; for Friar Laurence met them both,
As he in penance wandered through the forest;
Him he knew well, and guessed that it was she,
But, being masked, he was not sure of it;
Besides, she did intend confession
At Patrick's cell this even; and there she was not;
These likelihoods confirm her flight from hence.
Therefore, I pray you, stand not to discourse,
But mount you presently and meet with me
Upon the rising of the mountain foot
That leads toward Mantua, whither they are fled:
Dispatch, sweet gentlemen, and follow me. Exit.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Why, this it is to be a peevish girl,
That flies her fortune when it follows her.
I'll after, more to be revenged on Eglamour
Than for the love of reckless Silvia. Exit.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: And I will follow, more for Silvia's love
Than hate of Eglamour that goes with her. Exit.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: And I will follow, more to cross that love
Than hate for Silvia that is gone for love. Exit.

div.head: Act 5, Scene 3
div.stage: The frontiers of Mantua. The forest.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.l: Come, come,
Be patient; we must bring you to our captain.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: A thousand more mischances than this one
Have learned me how to brook this patiently.

sp.speaker: Second Outlaw
sp.l: Come, bring her away.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.l: Where is the gentleman that was with her?

sp.speaker: Third Outlaw
sp.l: Being nimble-footed, he hath outrun us,
But Moyses and Valerius follow him.
Go thou with her to the west end of the wood;
There is our captain: we'll follow him that's fled;
The thicket is beset; he cannot scape.

sp.speaker: First Outlaw
sp.l: Come, I must bring you to our captain's cave:
Fear not; he bears an honourable mind,
And will not use a woman lawlessly.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: O Valentine, this I endure for thee! Exeunt.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: How use doth breed a habit in a man!
This shadowy desert, unfrequented woods,
I better brook than flourishing peopled towns:
Here can I sit alone, unseen of any,
And to the nightingale's complaining notes
Tune my distresses and record my woes.
O thou that dost inhabit in my breast,
Leave not the mansion so long tenantless,
Lest, growing ruinous, the building fall
And leave no memory of what it was!
Repair me with thy presence, Silvia;
Thou gentle nymph, cherish thy forlorn swain
What halloing and what stir is this to-day?
These are my mates, that make their wills their law,
Have some unhappy passenger in chase.
They love me well; yet I have much to do
To keep them from uncivil outrages.
Withdraw thee, Valentine; who's this comes here? Enter PROTEUS, SILVIA, and JULIA.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Madam, this service I have done for you,
Though you respect not aught your servant doth,
To hazard life and rescue you from him
That would have forced your honour and your love;
Vouchsafe me, for my meed, but one fair look;
A smaller boon than this I cannot beg
And less than this, I am sure, you cannot give.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: How like a dream is this I see and hear!
Love, lend me patience to forbear awhile.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: O miserable, unhappy that I am!

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Unhappy were you, madam, ere I came;
But by my coming I have made you happy.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: By thy approach thou makest me most unhappy.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: And me, when he approacheth to your presence.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: Had I been seized by a hungry lion,
I would have been a breakfast to the beast,
Rather than have false Proteus rescue me.
O, Heaven be judge how I love Valentine,
Whose life's as tender to me as my soul!
And full as much, for more there cannot be,
I do detest false perjured Proteus.
Therefore be gone; solicit me no more.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: What dangerous action, stood it next to death,
Would I not undergo for one calm look!
O, 'tis the curse in love, and still approved,
When women cannot love where they're beloved!

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: When Proteus cannot love where he's beloved.
Read over Julia's heart, thy first best love,
For whose dear sake thou didst then rend thy faith
Into a thousand oaths; and all those oaths.
Descended into perjury, to love me.
Thou hast no faith left now, unless thou'dst two;
And that's far worse than none; better have none
Than plural faith which is too much by one:
Thou counterfeit to thy true friend!

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: In love
Who respects friend?

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: All men but Proteus.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Nay, if the gentle spirit of moving words
Can no way change you to a milder form,
I'll woo you like a soldier, at arms' end,
And love you 'gainst the nature of love, — force ye.

sp.speaker: Silvia
sp.l: O heaven!

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: I'll force thee yield to my desire.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: Ruffian, let go that rude uncivil touch,
Thou friend of an ill fashion!

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Valentine!

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: Thou common friend, that's without faith or love,
For such is a friend now; treacherous man!
Thou hast beguiled my hopes; nought but mine eye
Could have persuaded me: now I dare not say
I have one friend alive; thou wouldst disprove me.
Who should be trusted, when one's right hand
Is perjured to the bosom? Proteus,
I am sorry I must never trust thee more,
But count the world a stranger for thy sake.
The private wound is deepest: O time most accurst,
'Mongst all foes that a friend should be the worst!

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: My shame and guilt confounds me.
Forgive me, Valentine: if hearty sorrow
Be a sufficient ransom for offence,
I tender't here; I do as truly suffer.
As e'er I did commit.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: Then I am paid;
And once again I do receive thee honest.
Who by repentance is not satisfied
Is nor of heaven nor earth, for these are pleased.
By penitence the Eternal's wrath's appeased:
And, that my love may appear plain and free,
All that was mine in Silvia I give thee.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: O me unhappy!

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.ab: Look to the boy.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.ab: Why, boy! why, wag! how now! what's the matter? Look
up; speak.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.ab: O good sir, my master charged me to deliver a
ring to Madam Silvia, which, out of my neglect, was
never done.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Where is that ring, boy?

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Here 'tis; this is it.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: How! let me see:
Why, this is the ring I gave to Julia.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: O, cry you mercy, sir, I have mistook:
This is the ring you sent to Silvia.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: But how camest thou by this ring?
At my depart
I gave this unto Julia.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: And Julia herself did give it me;
And Julia herself hath brought it hither.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: How! Julia!

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: Behold her that gave aim to all thy oaths,
And entertained 'em deeply in her heart.
How oft hast thou with perjury cleft the root!
O Proteus, let this habit make thee blush!
Be thou ashamed that I have took upon me
Such an immodest raiment, if shame live
In a disguise of love:
It is the lesser blot, modesty finds,
Women to change their shapes than men their minds.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Than men their minds! 'tis true. O heaven! were man
But constant, he were perfect. That one error
Fills him with faults; makes him run through all the sins:
Inconstancy falls off ere it begins.
What is in Silvia's face, but I may spy
More fresh in Julia's with a constant eye?

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: Come, come, a hand from either:
Let me be blest to make this happy close;
'Twere pity two such friends should be long foes.

sp.speaker: Proteus
sp.l: Bear witness, Heaven, I have my wish for ever.

sp.speaker: Julia
sp.l: And I mine. Enter Outlaws, with DUKE and THURIO.

sp.speaker: Outlaws
sp.l: A prize, a prize, a prize!

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: Forbear, forbear, I say! it is my lord the duke.
Your grace is welcome to a man disgraced,
Banished Valentine.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Sir Valentine!

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Yonder is Silvia; and Silvia's mine.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: Thurio, give back, or else embrace thy death;
Come not within the measure of my wrath;
Do not name Silvia thine; if once again,
Milan shall not hold thee. Here she stands:
Take but possession of her with a touch:
I dare thee but to breathe upon my love.

sp.speaker: Thurio
sp.l: Sir Valentine, I care not for her, I:
I hold him but a fool that will endanger
His body for a girl that loves him not:
I claim her not, and therefore she is thine.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: The more degenerate and base art thou,
To make such means for her as thou hast done
And leave her on such slight conditions.
Now, by the honour of my ancestry,
I do applaud thy spirit, Valentine,
And think thee worthy of an empress' love:
Know then, I here forget all former griefs,
Cancel all grudge, repeal thee home again,
Plead a new state in thy unrivaled merit,
To which I thus subscribe: Sir Valentine,
Thou art a gentleman and well derived;
Take thou thy Silvia, for thou hast deserved her.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: I thank your grace; the gift hath made me happy.
I now beseech you, for your daughter's sake,
To grant one boon that I shall ask of you.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I grant it, for thine own, what e'er it be.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: These banished men that I have kept withal
Are men endued with worthy qualities:
Forgive them what they have committed here
And let them be recalled from their exile:
They are reformed, civil, full of good
And fit for great employment, worthy lord.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: Thou hast prevailed; I pardon them and thee;
Dispose of them as thou know'st their deserts.
Come, let us go: we will include all jars
With triumphs, mirth and rare solemnity.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: And, as we walk along, I dare be bold
With our discourse to make your grace to smile.
What think you of this page, my lord?

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: I think the boy hath grace in him; he blushes.

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: I warrant you, my lord, more grace than boy.

sp.speaker: Duke
sp.l: What mean you by that saying?

sp.speaker: Valentine
sp.l: Please you, I'll tell you as we pass along,
That you will wonder what hath fortuned.
Come, Proteus; 'tis your penance but to hear
The story of your loves discovered:
That done, our day of marriage shall be yours:
One feast, one house, one mutual happiness. Exeunt.
